bestBHT.bht: Rather than hindering the Gospel, the apostle Paul's imprisonment actually advanced it. The Philippians, who feared that his chains would impede the spread of the Good News, need not worry. Paul compares his situation to pioneers cutting a path before an army, overcoming obstacles and progressing towards wisdom. His sufferings were not chance, but divine appointment, and have ultimately furthered the cause of the Gospel, inspiring others to inquire about the Christian teaching. What may have seemed adverse has become an opportunity for the Gospel to flourish.

Henry Alford: 12. rather] i.e. than the contrary: not, ‘more now than before.’
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The Philippians probably had feared that his imprisonment would hinder the spread of the Gospel; he therefore removes this fear.
Faith takes in a favorable light even what seems adverse.
So far is my imprisonment from hindering the Gospel.
Albert Barnes: He wished them to understand what his circumstances were, and what had been the effect of his imprisonment...
He had real intelligence to communicate to them that would be joyful to them, about the effect of his imprisonment, and his treatment there; and he wished them to rejoice with him.
This arrest and imprisonment would seem to have been against his success as a preacher; but he now says that the contrary had been the fact.
Marvin Vincent: Rather [μαλλον] . For the furtherance of the Gospel rather than, as might have been expected, for its hindrance.
The metaphor is uncertain, but is supposed to be that of pioneers cutting [κοπτω] a way before [προ] an army, and so furthering its march.
The opposite is expressed by ejgkoptw to cut into; hence to throw obstacles in the way, hinder.
John Calvin: We allow, indeed, Christ crucified to be preached to us; but when he appears in connection with his cross, then, as though we were thunderstruck at the novelty of it, we either avoid him or hold him in abhorrence...
It may have happened to the Philippians, that they were in some degree discouraged in consequence of the persecution of their Apostle.
The design, accordingly, of this detail is, to encourage the Philippians, that they may not feel deterred by the persecution endured by him.
Philip Schaff: Thus he points out how the cause of the Gospel was served by his chains.
Many who would never have cared to inquire about Christian teaching were prompted to do so when told of this as the reason for the apostle’s imprisonment.

The expression ‘all other places,’ though seemingly hyperbolic, is not without its interest when we remember that one of the traditions concerning the first publication of the Gospel in Britain ascribes it to Roman soldiers who may have been the hearers of St. Paul in his prison.
Archibald T. Robertson: The things concerning me" = "my affairs" as common in Josephus.
It is a technical term in Stoic philosophy for 'progress toward wisdom' and it appears also in the papyri and the LXX.
John Gill: his sufferings on account of the Gospel, which though said to happen, were not things of chance but of appointment
the very things by which men designed to have hindered the spread of the Gospel [...] have fallen out rather unto the furtherance of the Gospel
persecution in one place has often been the means of carrying and spreading the Gospel in many others
John Wesley: The things concerning me — My sufferings. Have fallen out rather to the furtherance, than, as you feared, the hinderance, of the gospel.

bhtAttempts.bht: The imprisonment of the apostle Paul, rather than hindering the Gospel, actually advanced it. The Philippians, who had feared that his imprisonment would impede the spread of the Gospel, need not worry, for even in his chains, the Gospel was being furthered. Paul likens his situation to pioneers cutting a path before an army, overcoming obstacles and progressing towards wisdom. His sufferings on account of the Gospel were not mere chance, but divine appointment, and have ultimately advanced the cause of the Gospel, inspiring others to inquire about the Christian teaching. Thus, what may have seemed adverse has actually become an opportunity for the Gospel to flourish.

Rather than hindering the Gospel, the apostle Paul's imprisonment actually advanced it. The Philippians, who feared that his chains would impede the spread of the Good News, need not worry. Paul compares his situation to pioneers cutting a path before an army, overcoming obstacles and progressing towards wisdom. His sufferings were not chance, but divine appointment, and have ultimately furthered the cause of the Gospel, inspiring others to inquire about the Christian teaching. What may have seemed adverse has become an opportunity for the Gospel to flourish.

Paul's imprisonment, far from hindering the spread of the Gospel, actually contributed to its progress. The Philippians, who feared that his chains would impede the mission, need not worry. Paul compares his situation to pioneers cutting a path before an army, overcoming obstacles and progressing towards wisdom. His sufferings were not chance, but divine appointment, and have ultimately furthered the cause of the Gospel, inspiring others to inquire about the Christian teaching. Adversity has presented an opportunity for the Gospel to flourish.

Paul's imprisonment, rather than hindering the Gospel, actually advanced it. The Philippians need not fear that his chains would impede the spread of the Good News. Adversity has become an opportunity for the Gospel to flourish. By comparing his situation to pioneers cutting a path before an army, Paul emphasizes the progress and wisdom gained through suffering. His sufferings were not mere chance but divinely appointed to further the cause of the Gospel. This inspires others to inquire about the Christian teaching and spreads the message to all places.

Adversity has become an opportunity for the Gospel to flourish. By comparing his situation to pioneers cutting a path before an army, Paul highlights the advancement and wisdom gained through suffering. His sufferings were not chance but divinely appointed to further the cause of the Gospel. This inspires others to inquire about the Christian teaching and spreads the message to all places.
